Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Compounding Crises: Facing Hurricane Season in the Era of COVID-19

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration: This Rapid Response Research (RAPID) grant provides funding to assess participants’ crisis exposure, their threat perceptions, their self- and response-efficacy, their emotional responses and their engagement in health protective behaviors as relevant to COVID-19 and to hurricanes. As the 2020 hurricane season commences, millions of Americans residing in the Atlantic and Gulf of Mexico coasts will face the likely possibility of dual crises – COVID-19 and hurricane exposure – with competing mitigation strategies. Experts project that there will be four hurricanes that will develop into major hurricanes (Categories 3, 4, or 5) in the Atlantic during the 2020 hurricane season (June 1st – November 30th). Concurrently, many in the Atlantic and Gulf Coast states are seeing alarming increases in confirmed case of COVID-19. The confluence of crises in communities at risk for hurricane exposure may create an untenable and tragic situation where millions of people may be suddenly asked to flee from an approaching major hurricane to shelters, potentially imperiling themselves and others to COVID-19. Hurricane-force winds further compound the risk given the high potential for Coronavirus to spread via respiratory droplets, potentially creating super-spreading environments and fueling fears about going to shelters. Repeated exposure to such crises can tax individuals’ emotional states, leading to difficulties in functioning and decision making over time. The important theoretical and practical question is: “How do people make proactive decisions regarding the threat of a hurricane in the time of the COVID-19 pandemic?”<br/><br/>The research team conducts a prospective, longitudinal, epidemiological study of residents (n=1,683) from Texas and Florida, for whom the team has data on their exposure, behavior, and response to previous hurricanes. Participants are members of Ipsos’s KnowledgePanel, and complete two surveys: one at the beginning of the 2020 hurricane season and at the height of the first wave of the COVID-19 pandemic and the second after the threat of a major land-falling Category 3, 4, or 5 hurricane. The researchers assess participants’ crisis exposure, their threat perceptions, their self- and response-efficacy, their emotional responses and their engagement in health protective behaviors as relevant to COVID-19 and to hurricanes. Moreover, the team uses publicly available datasets to create geocoded variables that link participant location to objective indicators of disaster exposure to both COVID-19 (e.g., deaths per 10,000, daily cases) and the physical parameters of hurricanes (e.g., inundation flooding, wind speed, air temperature). This project examines individual’s response to repeated exposure to hurricanes in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic, using pre-COVID, prospectively collected data, objective markers of exposure, and a longitudinal design. The findings are useful to policymakers, service providers, educators, and members of the media to communicate messages and design interventions.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Repeated exposure to simultaneous crises can tax individuals' emotional state, leading to difficulties in functioning and decision making over time. As society grapples with escalating and compounding environmental, viral, and economic threats, it is important to understand the psychological processes that lead to risk, resilience, and recovery. The important theoretical and practical question posed in this project was: "How do people make proactive decisions regarding the threat of hurricanes in the time of the COVID-19 pandemic?" Thus, the major project goals were to assess participants' crisis exposure, threat perceptions, self- and response-efficacy, emotional responses, and engagement in health protective behaviors related to COVID-19 and to hurricanes over time. 

We conducted two waves of data collection with a representative sample of residents from Florida and Texas, for whom the team had access to three waves of existing data on respondents' exposure, behavior, and response to previous hurricanes. Of the original 2,774 respondents, 1,846 were surveyed May 14-27, 2020 before the 2020 hurricane season and during the height of the COVID-19 pandemic. The same respondents (N=1,479) were surveyed again at the end of the 2021 hurricane season (December 20, 2021-January 11, 2022). Respondents were assessed on their direct and media-based crisis exposure, threat perceptions, self- and response-efficacy, emotional responses and engagement in health protective behaviors as relevant to COVID-19 and to hurricanes. They were also assessed on their social support, as well as on their adaptation and mitigation behaviors regarding global environmental change. Residential latitude and longitude on each of the participants (shifted 100-2000 ft. to protect respondent privacy) used to determine Census tract IDs using ArcGIS software were also obtained. In addition, extensive demographic information (including income, age, gender, education, and race/ethnicity), pre-pandemic mental health, and political ideology were collected from participants. We integrated theories from decision science, disaster psychology, and stress and coping literatures to explore how individuals respond and adapt to co-occurring threats and how direct and media-based exposures shape responses over time. Results have the potential to inform public policy relevant to crisis communication, post-disaster psychological well-being, and mitigation and preparation for future threats including natural disasters and future viral outbreaks.

Key findings identified during the project period include:

  • Prior negative hurricane experiences and subjective attribution of those experiences to global environmental change were associated with the self-reported adoption of more hurricane-related protective behaviors.
  • Type and amount of crisis-related media exposure was associated with the performance of protective behavior relevant to COVID-19 and hurricanes, which in turn was mediated by threat perceptions and self-efficacy.  
  • Media exposure to traditional news sources (e.g., network and cable news) was associated with the adoption of protective behaviors, although exposure to social media was either not associated (in the case of hurricanes) or negatively associated (in the case of COVID-19) with protective behaviors. This underscores the danger of misinformation on social media damaging efforts to promote public health as well as the untapped potential of social media to encourage protective behavior.
  • Those with more prior hurricane exposure reported more posttraumatic stress symptoms and climate-related anxiety over time; however, only climate anxiety was associated with pro-environmental actions and attitudes.
  • Those reporting higher risk perceptions adopted greater measures to adapt to hurricanes. Over time, more adaptation was associated with lower risk perceptions. Risk perceptions regarding hurricane risk also decreased during periods of no hurricane activity.
  • Greater psychological distress was associated with greater consideration of migration, including appeal of moving, bother regarding events like hurricanes, and migration potential.

Overall, our study provides residents, communities, planners, practitioners, emergency managers, and public officials with detailed characterizations of how individuals respond to the threat of landfalling hurricanes while concurrently dealing with a global pandemic, providing evidence essential to allocating resources for disaster preparation, mobilization, and recovery.
